Award.AwardTitle: Effective Properties of Multi-phase Materials by Stochastic Reduced Order Models (SROMs)

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will develop a probabilistic method for calculating macroscopic properties of multi-phase and other random heterogeneous materials. Multi-phase materials are used extensively in practice since their properties can be tuned to particular applications by altering the volume fraction, geometry, and physical properties of their constituents. For example, the structural members of the Voyager aircraft, that has flown nonstop around the world without midair refueling, were made of graphite fibers; portland and asphaltic cement concretes are used extensively as structural and paving materials; and carbon fiber cement matrix composites have been applied successfully in electronics. Stochastic reduced order models will be used to characterize properties of random heterogeneous materials at small scale and calculate macroscopic properties of these materials.

The project will have a notable theoretical impact on both the formulation and solution of a broad range of problems in science and engineering since these problems can be described by equations with random coefficients/input, and stochastic reduced order models provide an efficient tool for solving these equations. The proposed research is expected to have a significant practical impact since it can be applied to solve large scale problems in civil and mechanical engineering. The project will also contribute to both graduate and undergraduate education. For example, an undergraduate student will be involved in all aspects of the proposed research and will lecture on his/her work in a popular undergraduate course on continuum mechanics to gain teaching experience and motivate undergraduates to do research and consider graduate studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Material properties at small scale vary randomly in space, e.g.,atomic lattice orientations fluctuate randomly from grain to grainand inclusions of two-phase materials have random shapes andlocations, and so do stresses, strains, and other materialresponses relevant for design.  The calculation of these materialresponses poses notable difficulties since they satisfydifferential equations with random coefficients, referred to asstochastic differential equations.  Monte Carlo simulation, theonly general method for solving stochastic equations, isimpractical when dealing with realistic applications.


The main outcome of this project is a practical method for solvingthe class of stochastic equations whose solutions are materialresponses at small scale. The implementation of the methodinvolves three steps. First, material properties are characterizedby parametric random fields, i.e., deterministic functions ofspace which depend on random vectors. Second, the random vectorsin the definition of the parametric random fields for materialproperties are represented by stochastic reduced order models(SROMs), i.e., random vectors with finite numbers of samples whichare selected in optimal manner. Third, deterministic solvers areused to calculate material responses corresponding to the samplesof SROMs and construct approximations for material responses. Theoretical arguments have been used to bound the error of theproposed approximate solution and show that it converges to theexact solution.  Numerical examples have been presented todemonstrate the implementation of the method and illustrate itsperformance.
